description: Suman Roy is a skilled Bengali food maker. He is an experienced chef with a good knowledge of various Bengali recipes. He has extensive knowledge of Bangladeshi and foreign cuisine and creates new recipes by experimenting with different foods.

recipes.recipe_name: Shorshe Ilish (Hilsa fish in mustard sauce)
recipes.cooking_method:
1. Mix mustard paste, turmeric powder, red chili powder, salt, sugar and mustard oil in a bowl.
2. Rub the mixture over the fish pieces and keep aside for 15-20 minutes.
3. Heat a pan and add the marinated fish pieces to it. Cook on medium flame for 2-3 minutes on each side.
4. Add water and cook for 5-6 minutes till the fish is cooked and the gravy thickens.
5. Serve hot with steamed rice.

1. Rinse the rice in cold water and soak for 30 minutes.
2. Heat oil in a large saucepan. Add onion and sauté until lightly browned. Add the bay leaf, cloves, cinnamon stick, and cardamom pods. Stir well.
3. Add the rice and stir to coat with the oil and spices. Add water and salt. Bring to a boil.
4. Reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until rice is cooked and water is absorbed.
5. Remove from heat and stir in the raisins and cashews. Cover and let stand for 10 minutes. Fluff with a fork before serving.

description: Riya Basu is a talented Bengali food maker who specializes in traditional Bengali dishes. She has a wealth of knowledge about the cultural significance of various Bengali foods and prepares them with great care and attention to detail.

recipes.cooking_method:
1. Heat oil in a large saucepan. Add onion and garlic and sauté until lightly browned. Add tomato puree and cook for a few minutes. Add cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, cayenne pepper, and salt. Stir well.
2. Add the fish fillets and cook for 5-10 minutes or until cooked through.
3. Add water and simmer for a few more minutes. Adjust seasoning if necessary.

ingredients: 1 lb. boneless chicken breast, cut into bite-sized pieces
recipes.cooking_method:
1. In a bowl, whisk together the yogurt, lemon juice, cumin, paprika, garam masala, ground ginger, cayenne pepper, and salt. Add the chicken and stir until coated. Marinate in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes.
2. Heat the butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic and grated ginger and cook for another minute. Add the turmeric and cayenne pepper and cook for 30 seconds.
3. Add the tomato puree and bring to a simmer. Cook for 5 minutes.
4. Add the chicken and its marinade to the skillet. Cook for about 10 minutes or until the chicken is cooked through.
5. Stir in the cream and heat through. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
6. Serve garnished with cilantro, if desired.

description: Arjun Gupta is a renowned Bengali food maker with over two decades of experience in the industry. He is known for his innovative approach to cooking and has created several new Bengali dishes that have become popular among food lovers.

1. Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Cut the top off the garlic head and drizzle with olive oil. Wrap in aluminum foil and roast for 30-40 minutes.
2. Heat olive oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add onion and sauté for 3-4 minutes or until translucent. Add chopped tomatoes and cook for another 3-4 minutes.
3. Squeeze the roasted garlic cloves out of their skins and add them to the pot. Add chicken broth and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and let simmer for 15-20 minutes.
4. Use an immersion blender or transfer the soup to a blender to puree until smooth. Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper to taste.
